subject: Re: Tesing-testing
author: Fiona Broome
full_text:
Hi,

It seems to me that there's plenty of room for individuality and personal opinion.  

However, I'm not sure if everyone understands that this is a Yahoo Group.  It's not a democracy and it's not an anarchy... it's whatever the group Owner/Moderator decides it is.

Frank started this group.  Frank stated the rules pretty clearly on the homepage. I didn't join with the idea that the rules were optional, or open for discussion.  (I've been running a few non-paranormal Yahoo Groups since the late 1990s, and Frank is vastly more tolerant than I am.)

I'm here to learn what Frank and others are discovering with various audio devices. Until I heard Chris Moon working with a box in Canada, I was a fairly rabid skeptic regarding this subject. Now, I'm eager to learn everything that I can about how this works.  (I rarely do 180-degree turns like that.)

The interruptions by critics -- leaping in rather prematurely, in my opinion -- are about as annoying as the flashes of apparently useless noise that interrupt the box and recordings.  

I don't see Frank being defensive about the possible theories involved, but keeping the group on track. I appreciate that. I nearly quit the group shortly after joining, because I don't have time to read snarks and flames... only interesting questions and results. 

I'm sorry that you don't hear anything extraordinary (and very clear) in at least some of the recordings. I'm not sure if you're asking for help, or what your purpose is with these comments.

Sincerely,
Fiona

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Rj <rasterer@...> wrote:
>
> You claim I don't listen to any of this stuff because I can't take the chance I might hear something.  I do listen to some of them.   I hear stuff.  But I don't hear anything that I can't explain by simple pareidolia or random radio transmissions. So you're wrong there.
> 
> In fact, to try to control for my own pareidolia, that is why I suggest the files not be labeled or explained.  That would help make listening to them a little less likely to be influenced by the perceptions of others, or made to "fit their personal expectation" as you noted.
> 
> I continue to be at a loss as to why Frank is so defensive when people disagree with him.  If I don't listen or comment, Frank attacks me.  If I do listen and 
> comment, Frank attacks me.  Is there no room for individuality and personal opinion? 
>
